title: What's the partial derivative of f (x, y) = log to the base x (y)? - Quora

response.answer_text: A partial derivative of a function is nothing but its derivative with respect to specific variables. Since the question has not mentioned anything specific, I am just going to differentiate it with respect to [math]x[/math] and [math]y[/math] separately. [math]f(x,y) = \displaystyle\frac{\ln y}{\ln x}[/math] I skipped a step here, as I just applied the change of base formula to the parent function in the question. Now, let’s differentiate with respect to [math]y[/math]: [math]\dfrac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y} = \dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{\ln y}{\ln x}}{\partial y}[/math] Rule #1 in partial differentiation is to check the variable you are differentiating with respect to and shove out whatever doesn’t contain your variable as a constant. [math]\dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{\ln y}{\ln x}}{\partial y} = \displaystyle\frac{(\ln y)'}{\ln x}[/math] Since the [math]\displaystyle\frac{1}{\ln x}[/math] doesn’t have a [math]y[/math] term, I could shove it out of my function as a constant. [math]\displaystyle\frac{(\ln y)'}{\ln x} = \displaystyle\frac{1}{y \cdot\ \ln x}[/math] Therefore, [math]\dfrac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y} = \displaystyle\frac{1}{y\cdot\ \ln x}[/math] Now, let’s differentiate with respect to [math]x[/math]: [math]\dfrac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x} = \displaystyle\dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{\ln y}{\ln x}}{\partial x}[/math] Like I mentioned earlier, the [math]\ln y[/math] term can be shoved out of the function as a constant, since it does not have an [math]x[/math] term. [math]\dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{\ln y}{\ln x}}{\partial x} = \ln y \cdot\ \displaystyle\dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{1}{\ln x}}{\partial x}[/math] Apply the chain rule to find the derivative of [math]\displaystyle\frac{1}{\ln x}[/math] [math]\ln y \cdot\ \dfrac{\partial \displaystyle\frac{1}{\ln x}}{\partial x} = \displaystyle\frac{-\ln y}{x \cdot\ (\ln(x))^{2}}[/math] Hope this helped!
